paper_metadata.title: Long-run effects of a 'big-push' program providing asset transfer to the poorest Indian households

program_information.target_population: Ultra-poor households meeting specific eligibility criteria

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: In addition to the asset, they received weekly consumption support for 30-40 weeks

component_b_assets.assets_evidence_citation: Households in the treatment group who chose to participate chose a productive asset from a menu of options (two cows, four goats, one cow and two goats, nonfarm microenterprise inventory, etc). About 82 percent chose livestock.

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: To collect information on baseline household characteristics, the research team administered a survey prior to the distribution of assets in 2007-2008, recording household demographics, consumption, food security, asset ownership, income, income sources, financial inclusion, adult time use, and physical and mental well-being.
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: Roughly half of these (514) were randomly assigned to receive the intervention, with stratification at the hamlet level.

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: In particular, the 'Targeting the Ultra Poor' (TUP) intervention, pioneered by BRAC in Bangladesh
evidence_citations.country_citation: The nongovernmental organization Bandhan ran the TUP program in West Bengal starting in 2007
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: Among households ranked in the bottom quintile, Bandhan then verified eligibility per seven criteria: (i) presence of an able-bodied female member (to manage the asset), (ii) no credit access, (iii) landholding below 0.2 acres, (iv) no ownership of productive assets, (v) no able-bodied male member, (vi) presence of school-aged children who were working instead of attending school, and (vii) primary source of income being informal labor or begging.
